title: Gravitational field-weight of object at sea level

content.question: A student has a calibrated spring scale that measures force with a precision of <math alttext="plus or minus 0.05 newton" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>±</mo><mn>0</mn><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mtext>.</mtext></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mn>05</mn></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mtext>N</mtext></mstyle></mstyle></math>. At sea level, the student holds the scale vertically with a <math alttext="100 gram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> object attached to it, and the scale reads <math alttext="1.00 newton" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>00</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></math>. The student then brings the scale and the object to the top of a <math alttext="1000 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1000</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> high mountain and again holds the scale vertically with the <math alttext="100 gram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></math> object attached. Which of the following correctly describes the scale’s reading, and provides valid justification for the claim?

choices.label: The scale reading is between <math alttext="0.90 newton" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>90</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></math> and <math alttext="0.99 newton" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>99</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></math>, because the scale is not precise enough to read the exact value of the object’s weight.

The scale reading is between <math alttext="0.90 newton" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.90</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> and <math alttext="0.99 newton" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.99</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>, because the weight of the object is inversely proportional to the square of the distance to the center of Earth.

The scale reading is between <math alttext="0.95 newton" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.95</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> and <math alttext="1.05 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.05</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>, because the height of the mountain is negligible compared to the radius of the earth.

The scale reading is between <math alttext="0.95 newton" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.95</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> and <math alttext="1.05 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.05</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>, because weight is an intrinsic property of an object which doesn’t change even when the gravitational field changes.

content.answer: The scale reading is between <math alttext="0.95 newton" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.95</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> and <math alttext="1.05 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.05</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>, because the height of the mountain is negligible compared to the radius of the earth.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
